title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: betaregscale package provides maximum-likelihood estimation beta regression models responses derived bounded rating scales. Common examples include pain intensity scales (NRS-11, NRS-21, NRS-101), Likert-type scales, product quality ratings, instrument whose response can mapped open interval (0,1)(0, 1). key idea discrete score recorded bounded scale carries measurement uncertainty inherent instrument. instance, pain score y=6y = 6 0‚Äì10 NRS exact value rather represents range: rescaling (0,1)(0, 1), observation treated interval-censored [0.55,0.65][0.55, 0.65]. package uses beta distribution model data, building complete likelihood supports mixed censoring types within dataset.

title: Introduction to betaregscale
code: # Development version from GitHub: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("evandeilton/betaregscale") library(betaregscale)

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: complete likelihood (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) supports four censoring types, automatically classified check_response(): f(‚ãÖ)f(\cdot) F(‚ãÖ)F(\cdot) beta density CDF, [li,ui][l_i, u_i] interval endpoints, (ai,bi)(a_i, b_i) beta shape parameters derived Œºi\mu_i œïi\phi_i via chosen reparameterization.

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: Scale observations mapped (0,1)(0, 1) uncertainty intervals controlled type argument: "m" (midpoint): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí0.5/K,yt+0.5/K][y_t - 0.5/K,\; y_t + 0.5/K] "l" (left-aligned): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt,yt+1/K][y_t,\; y_t + 1/K] "r" (right-aligned): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí1/K,yt][y_t - 1/K,\; y_t] KK number scale categories (ncuts). delta column shows y=0y = 0 left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta = 1), y=10y = 10 right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta = 2), interior values interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta = 3).

title: Introduction to betaregscale
text: package supports three reparameterizations beta distribution, controlled repar argument: Direct (repar = 0): Shape parameters =Œºa = \mu b=œïb = \phi used directly. rarely used practice. Precision (repar = 1, Ferrari & Cribari-Neto, 2004): mean Œº‚àà(0,1)\mu \(0,1) precision œï>0\phi > 0 yield =Œºœïa = \mu\phi b=(1‚àíŒº)œïb = (1-\mu)\phi. Higher œï\phi means less variability. Mean‚Äìvariance (repar = 2): mean Œº‚àà(0,1)\mu \(0,1) dispersion œï‚àà(0,1)\phi \(0,1) yield =Œº(1‚àíœï)/œïa = \mu(1-\phi)/\phi b=(1‚àíŒº)(1‚àíœï)/œïb = (1-\mu)(1-\phi)/\phi. œï\phi acts coefficient variation: smaller œï\phi means less variability.
code: # Precision parameterization: mu = 0.5, phi = 10 (high precision) beta_reparam(mu = 0.5, phi = 10, repar = 1) #>   shape1 shape2 #> 1      5      5  # Mean-variance parameterization: mu = 0.5, phi = 0.1 (low dispersion) beta_reparam(mu = 0.5, phi = 0.1, repar = 2) #>   shape1 shape2 #> 1    4.5    4.5

what: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Beta Regression Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes betaregscale package provides maximum-likelihood estimation beta regression models responses derived bounded rating scales (e.g., NRS-11, NRS-21, NRS-101, Likert scales). Observations treated interval-censored (0, 1) scale--unit transformation, likelihood built beta CDF evaluated interval endpoints. package designed situations recorded score carries measurement uncertainty inherent instrument. example, pain score 6 0‚Äì10 NRS scale interpreted lying interval [5.5, 6.5] rescaling (0, 1). complete likelihood (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) supports mixed censoring types‚Äîuncensored, left-censored, right-censored, interval-censored‚Äîwithin dataset.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Mixed censoring support ‚Äî complete likelihood handles four censoring types simultaneously: exact observations (Œ¥=0\delta=0), left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta=1), right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta=2), interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta=3). Fixed variable dispersion ‚Äî model scalar œï\phi let depend covariates via second linear predictor (y ~ x1 + x2 | z1). High-performance C++ backend ‚Äî log-likelihood analytical gradient compiled via Rcpp/RcppArmadillo fast, numerically stable estimation. Flexible link functions ‚Äî logit, probit, cauchit, cloglog mean; logit, log, identity, sqrt, inverse, others dispersion. Three reparameterizations ‚Äî direct (0), Ferrari‚ÄìCribari-Neto precision (1), mean‚Äìvariance (2). betareg-style S3 interface ‚Äî print, summary, coef, vcov, logLik, AIC, BIC, nobs, formula, model.matrix, fitted, residuals, predict, confint, plot methods. coef() vcov() methods accept model = c("full", "mean", "precision"). Diagnostic plots ‚Äî six residual diagnostic panels base R ggplot2 backends, including half-normal envelope plot. Censoring summary ‚Äî censoring_summary() provides visual tabular summaries censoring structure. Simulation toolkit ‚Äî betaregscale_simulate() betaregscale_simulate_z() Monte Carlo studies.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: # Development version from GitHub: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("evandeilton/betaregscale")

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: library(betaregscale)  # Simulate interval-censored data from a fixed-dispersion model set.seed(42) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.3, -0.6, 0.4), phi = 1/10,   link = "logit", link_phi = "logit",   ncuts = 100, type = "m", repar = 2 ) head(sim)  # Fit the model fit <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim, repar = 2) summary(fit)

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: # Simulate data with covariate-dependent dispersion set.seed(2222) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(   x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n),   z1 = rnorm(n), z2 = rnorm(n) ) sim_z <- betaregscale_simulate_z(   formula_x = ~ x1 + x2, formula_z = ~ z1,   data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.6, 0.2),   zeta = c(0.2, -0.8),   link = "logit", link_phi = "logit",   ncuts = 100, type = "m", repar = 2 )  # Fit variable-dispersion model (pipe notation) fit_z <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2 | z1, data = sim_z, repar = 2) summary(fit_z)

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: links <- c("logit", "probit", "cauchit", "cloglog") fits <- lapply(setNames(links, links), function(lnk) {   betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim, link = lnk, repar = 2) })  # Goodness-of-fit comparison do.call(rbind, lapply(fits, gof))

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
code: # Coefficients by submodel coef(fit)                          # full parameter vector coef(fit, model = "mean")         # mean submodel only coef(fit, model = "precision")    # precision submodel only  # Variance-covariance matrix vcov(fit, model = "mean")  # Wald confidence intervals confint(fit)  # Predictions predict(fit, type = "response")    # fitted means predict(fit, type = "precision")   # fitted dispersion predict(fit, type = "variance")    # conditional variance predict(fit, type = "quantile", at = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75))  # Residuals residuals(fit, type = "pearson") residuals(fit, type = "rqr")       # randomized quantile residuals  # Diagnostic plots (base R) plot(fit)  # Diagnostic plots (ggplot2, if installed) plot(fit, gg = TRUE)  # Censoring structure summary censoring_summary(fit)

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: complete log-likelihood mixed censoring (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) combines four observation types: ‚Ñì(ùõâ)=‚àë:Œ¥i=0logf(yi)+‚àë:Œ¥i=1logF(ui)+‚àë:Œ¥i=2log[1‚àíF(li)]+‚àë:Œ¥i=3log[F(ui)‚àíF(li)] \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \sum_{:\,\delta_i=0} \log f(y_i) + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=1} \log F(u_i) + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=2} \log [1 - F(l_i)] + \sum_{:\,\delta_i=3} \log [F(u_i) - F(l_i)] f(‚ãÖ)f(\cdot) F(‚ãÖ)F(\cdot) beta density CDF, [li,ui][l_i, u_i] interval endpoints, Œ¥i\delta_i indicates censoring type.

title: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes
text: Scale observations mapped (0, 1) uncertainty intervals whose width depends type parameter: "m" (midpoint): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí0.5/K,yt+0.5/K][y_t - 0.5/K,\; y_t + 0.5/K] "l" (left): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt,yt+1/K][y_t,\; y_t + 1/K] "r" (right): yt=y/Ky_t = y/K, interval [yt‚àí1/K,yt][y_t - 1/K,\; y_t] KK number scale categories (ncuts).

title: Reparameterize (mu, phi) into beta shape parameters ‚Äî beta_reparam
text: three schemes : repar = 0 Direct: \(= \mu,\; b = \phi\). repar = 1 Ferrari‚ÄìCribari-Neto:     \(= \mu\phi,\; b = (1 - \mu)\phi\), \(\phi\)     acts precision parameter. repar = 2 Mean‚Äìvariance:     \(= \mu(1-\phi)/\phi,\; b = (1-\mu)(1-\phi)/\phi\),     \(\phi \(0,1)\) analogous coefficient     variation.

title: betaregscale: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes ‚Äî betaregscale-package
text: Maximum-likelihood estimation beta regression models responses derived bounded rating scales. Observations treated interval-censored (0, 1) scale--unit transformation. complete likelihood supports mixed censoring types: uncensored (exact), left-censored, right-censored, interval-censored observations (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24). fixed- variable-dispersion submodels supported, flexible link functions mean precision components. compiled C++ backend (via Rcpp RcppArmadillo) provides numerically stable, high-performance log-likelihood evaluation.

title: betaregscale: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes ‚Äî betaregscale-package
text: betaregscale Unified fitting interface     fixed- variable-dispersion models. betaregscale_fit Fit fixed-dispersion model. betaregscale_fit_z Fit variable-dispersion model. betaregscale_loglik Compute log-likelihood     (fixed dispersion). betaregscale_loglik_z Compute log-likelihood     (variable dispersion). betaregscale_simulate Simulate interval-censored     data fixed-dispersion beta model. betaregscale_simulate_z Simulate data     variable-dispersion beta model. censoring_summary Visual tabular summary     censoring structure. bs_prepare Pre-process analyst data (validate,     classify censoring, rescale) model fitting.

title: betaregscale: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes ‚Äî betaregscale-package
text: Objects class "betaregscale" support: print, summary, coef, vcov, logLik, AIC, BIC, nobs, formula, model.matrix, fitted, residuals, predict, confint, plot. coef() vcov() methods accept model = c("full", "mean", "precision") argument following betareg package convention.

title: betaregscale: Beta Regression for Interval-Censored Scale-Derived Outcomes ‚Äî betaregscale-package
text: complete likelihood (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24) supports four censoring types, classified automatically check_response: \(\delta = 0\) (exact) Continuous observations (0, 1). \(\delta = 1\) (left-censored) Observations scale     minimum (y = 0). \(\delta = 2\) (right-censored) Observations scale     maximum (y = ncuts). \(\delta = 3\) (interval-censored) Standard scale     observations boundaries.

code: set.seed(42) n <- 100 dat <- data.frame(   x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n),   z1 = runif(n) ) sim <- betaregscale_simulate_z(   formula_x = ~ x1 + x2, formula_z = ~z1,   data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3),   zeta = c(1, 1.2) )  # Fixed dispersion fit1 <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim) print(fit1) #>  #> Call: #> betaregscale(formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim) #>  #> Coefficients (mean model with logit link): #> (Intercept)          x1          x2  #>      0.0959     -0.3912      0.2964  #>  #> Phi coefficients (precision model with logit link): #>  (phi)  #> 1.4895  #>   # Variable dispersion fit2 <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2 | z1, data = sim) print(fit2) #>  #> Call: #> betaregscale(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 | z1, data = sim) #>  #> Coefficients (mean model with logit link): #> (Intercept)          x1          x2  #>      0.0959     -0.3912      0.2965  #>  #> Phi coefficients (precision model with logit link): #> (phi)_(Intercept)          (phi)_z1  #>            1.4876            0.0040  #>

text: Computes total log-likelihood beta regression model mixed-censored responses single (scalar) dispersion parameter. heavy computation delegated compiled C++ backend.

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
text: param Numeric vector length \(p + 1\): first \(p\) elements regression coefficients \(\beta\), last element (link-scale) dispersion parameter. formula One-sided two-sided formula mean model. data Data frame containing response predictors. link Character: link function mean (default "logit"). link_phi Character: link function dispersion (default "logit"). ncuts Integer: number scale categories (default 100). type Character: interval type ("m", "l", "r"). lim Numeric: half-width uncertainty region (default 0.5). repar Integer: reparameterization scheme (0, 1, 2; default 2).

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
text: Scalar: total log-likelihood.

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
text: complete likelihood observation \(\) censoring indicator \(\delta_i\) (Lopes, 2024, Eq. 2.24): \(\delta = 0\) (uncensored) \(\ell_i = \log f(y_i | a_i, b_i)\) \(\delta = 1\) (left-censored) \(\ell_i = \log F(u_i | a_i, b_i)\) \(\delta = 2\) (right-censored) \(\ell_i = \log(1 - F(l_i | a_i, b_i))\) \(\delta = 3\) (interval-censored) \(\ell_i = \log(F(u_i | a_i, b_i) - F(l_i | a_i, b_i))\) \(a_i\) \(b_i\) beta shape parameters derived mean \(\mu_i = g^{-1}(x_i'\beta)\) scalar dispersion \(\phi = h^{-1}(\gamma)\) chosen reparameterization.

title: Log-likelihood for fixed-dispersion beta interval regression ‚Äî betaregscale_loglik
code: set.seed(42) n <- 100 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0, 0.5, -0.2), phi = 1 / 5 ) betaregscale_loglik(   param = c(0, 0.5, -0.2, 1 / 5),   formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = sim ) #> [1] -417.4957

what: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: Validates transforms raw data format required betaregscale. analyst can supply data several ways: Minimal: score y. Censoring     inferred automatically (equivalent check_response). Classic: y + explicit delta.     analyst states censoring type; interval endpoints computed. Interval: left /right columns     (original scale). Censoring inferred NA pattern. Full: y, left, right     together. analyst's endpoints rescaled directly     \((0, 1)\). covariate columns preserved unchanged output data frame.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
code: bs_prepare(   data,   y = "y",   delta = "delta",   left = "left",   right = "right",   ncuts = 100L,   type = "m",   lim = 0.5 )

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: data data.frame containing response (optionally) covariates. y Character: name score column (default "y"). delta Character: name censoring indicator column (default "delta"). Values must {0, 1, 2, 3}. left Character: name left-endpoint column (default "left"). right Character: name right-endpoint column (default "right"). ncuts Integer: number scale categories (default 100). type Character: interval type interior scores y delta available. "m" = midpoint (default), "l" = left-aligned, "r" = right-aligned. See check_response. lim Numeric: half-width uncertainty region (default 0.5). Used constructing intervals y alone.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: data.frame following columns appended   replaced: left Lower endpoint \((0, 1)\). right Upper endpoint \((0, 1)\). yt Midpoint approximation \((0, 1)\). y Original scale value (preserved reference). delta Censoring indicator: 0 = exact, 1 = left,       2 = right, 3 = interval. Covariate columns preserved.   output carries attributes "bs_prepared" (TRUE),   "ncuts", "type", "lim"   betaregscale can detect prepared data skip   internal check_response call.

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
text: Priority rule: delta provided (non-NA), takes precedence. delta NA, function infers censoring type pattern left, right, y: y, left, right present observation, analyst's left/right values used directly (rescaled \(K =\) ncuts) delta set 3 (interval-censored) unless analyst supplied delta explicitly. endpoints clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\) \(\epsilon = 10^{-5}\).

title: Pre-process analyst data for beta interval regression ‚Äî bs_prepare
code: # --- Mode 1: y only (automatic classification, like check_response) --- d1 <- data.frame(y = c(0, 3, 5, 7, 10), x1 = rnorm(5)) bs_prepare(d1, ncuts = 10) #> bs_prepare: n = 5 | exact = 0, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 3 #>      left   right      yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 0.00001 0.05000 0.00001  0     1  0.5029463 #> 2 0.25000 0.35000 0.30000  3     3  0.9688992 #> 3 0.45000 0.55000 0.50000  5     3 -0.8757371 #> 4 0.65000 0.75000 0.70000  7     3 -2.1360245 #> 5 0.95000 0.99999 0.99999 10     2 -1.5228276  # --- Mode 2: y + explicit delta --- d2 <- data.frame(   y     = c(50, 0, 99, 50),   delta = c(0, 1, 2, 3),   x1    = rnorm(4) ) bs_prepare(d2, ncuts = 100) #> Warning: Observation(s) 3: delta = 2 (right-censored) but y != 100. #> bs_prepare: n = 4 | exact = 1, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 1 #>      left   right      yt  y delta           x1 #> 1 0.50000 0.50000 0.50000 50     0 -1.113118208 #> 2 0.00001 0.00500 0.00001  0     1  1.240983896 #> 3 0.99500 0.99999 0.99999 99     2  0.003481935 #> 4 0.49500 0.50500 0.50000 50     3 -1.237794586  # --- Mode 3: left/right with NA patterns --- d3 <- data.frame(   left  = c(NA, 20, 30, NA),   right = c(5, NA, 45, NA),   y     = c(NA, NA, NA, 50),   x1    = rnorm(4) ) bs_prepare(d3, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 4 | exact = 1, left = 1, right = 1, interval = 1 #>    left   right    yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 1e-05 0.05000 0.025 NA     1  0.5556991 #> 2 2e-01 0.99999 0.600 NA     2 -2.1831493 #> 3 3e-01 0.45000 0.375 NA     3 -0.2470245 #> 4 5e-01 0.50000 0.500 50     0  1.1128569  # --- Mode 4: y + left + right (analyst-supplied intervals) --- d4 <- data.frame(   y     = c(50, 75),   left  = c(48, 73),   right = c(52, 77),   x1    = rnorm(2) ) bs_prepare(d4, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 2 | exact = 0, left = 0, right = 0, interval = 2 #>   left right   yt  y delta         x1 #> 1 0.48  0.52 0.50 50     3 -0.3416732 #> 2 0.73  0.77 0.75 75     3  1.3054383  # --- End-to-end workflow --- # \donttest{ set.seed(42) n <- 200 dat <- data.frame(x1 = rnorm(n), x2 = rnorm(n)) sim <- betaregscale_simulate(   formula = ~ x1 + x2, data = dat,   beta = c(0.2, -0.5, 0.3), phi = 1 / 5 ) prep <- bs_prepare(sim, ncuts = 100) #> bs_prepare: n = 200 | exact = 0, left = 18, right = 21, interval = 161 fit <- betaregscale(y ~ x1 + x2, data = prep) summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> betaregscale(formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = prep) #>  #> Quantile residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -3.0625 -0.5896  0.2555  0.6723  1.5528  #>  #> Coefficients (mean model with logit link): #>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept) -5.15677    0.08757 -58.886  < 2e-16 *** #> x1          -0.38266    0.06216  -6.156 7.45e-10 *** #> x2           0.12275    0.06556   1.872   0.0612 .   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‚Äò***‚Äô 0.001 ‚Äò**‚Äô 0.01 ‚Äò*‚Äô 0.05 ‚Äò.‚Äô 0.1 ‚Äò ‚Äô 1 #>  #> Phi coefficients (precision model with logit link): #>       Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (phi)  -4.8810     0.1352  -36.11   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‚Äò***‚Äô 0.001 ‚Äò**‚Äô 0.01 ‚Äò*‚Äô 0.05 ‚Äò.‚Äô 0.1 ‚Äò ‚Äô 1 #> --- #> Log-likelihood: -896.1340 on 4 Df #> Pseudo R-squared: 0.1097  #> Number of iterations: 29 (BFGS)  #> Censoring: 161 interval | 18 left | 21 right  #>  # }

what: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: Takes discrete (continuous) response scale \(0, 1, \ldots, K\) (\(K =\) ncuts) converts pair interval endpoints open unit interval \((0, 1)\).  observation classified one four censoring types following complete likelihood Lopes (2024, Eq. 2.24): \(\delta = 0\) Uncensored (exact): observation     continuous value already \((0, 1)\).  likelihood     contribution density \(f(y_i | \theta)\). \(\delta = 1\) Left-censored: observation equals     scale minimum (\(y = 0\)).  know latent     value upper bound.  contribution     \(F(u_i | \theta)\). \(\delta = 2\) Right-censored: observation equals     scale maximum (\(y = K\)).  contribution     \(1 - F(l_i | \theta)\). \(\delta = 3\) Interval-censored: standard case     scale data.  contribution     \(F(u_i | \theta) - F(l_i | \theta)\).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
code: check_response(y, type = "m", ncuts = 100L, lim = 0.5)

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: y Numeric vector ‚Äî raw response. type Character: interval type. "m" = midpoint (default), "l" = left-aligned, "r" = right-aligned. ncuts Integer: number scale categories (default 100). lim Numeric: half-width uncertainty region (default 0.5).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: matrix columns left, right,   yt (midpoint approximation), y (original   value), delta (censoring indicator: 0 = exact,   1 = left, 2 = right, 3 = interval).

title: Transform and validate a scale-derived response variable ‚Äî check_response
text: input already \((0, 1)\) (.e., values satisfy \(0 < y < 1\)), observations treated uncensored (\(\delta = 0\)). scale (integer) data: \(y = 0\): left-censored. Upper bound     \(u = \mathrm{lim} / K\). \(y = K\): right-censored. Lower bound     \(l = (K - \mathrm{lim}) / K\). \(0 < y < K\): interval-censored endpoints determined     interval type. Three interval types (Section 2.7, Figure 4 Lopes, 2024): "m" (midpoint) Symmetric: \(l = (y - \mathrm{lim})/K\),     \(u = (y + \mathrm{lim})/K\). "l" (left) Shifted left: \(l = (y - 2\mathrm{lim})/K\),     \(u = y/K\). "r" (right) Shifted right: \(l = y/K\),     \(u = (y + 2\mathrm{lim})/K\). endpoints clamped \([\epsilon, 1 - \epsilon]\) \(\epsilon = 10^{-5}\) avoid boundary issues beta likelihood.

title: betaregscale 2.0.1
text: bs_prepare() data preprocessing: new analyst-facing function validates, classifies censoring, rescales raw data model fitting. Supports four flexible input modes: score-, score + explicit delta, interval endpoints NA patterns, analyst-supplied left/right bounds. Prepared data automatically detected betaregscale(). Internal helper .extract_response() enables transparent detection bs_prepare()-processed data across fitting, log-likelihood, starting-value functions. censoring_summary() now also accepts data frames bs_prepare(). New vignette section documenting four data preparation modes.

title: betaregscale 2.0.1
text: Fixed potential row-indexing bug bs_prepare() receives subset data frame non-sequential row names. Output now always sequential row names (1:n).

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Removed dependency bbmle. model fitting now uses stats::optim() directly analytical gradients via C++ backend. betaregscale_bbmle() function removed. cumulative parameter replaced delta indicator vector, supports mixed censoring types within dataset. Parameter dados renamed data across functions. Simulation functions renamed: betaregscale_simula_dados() now betaregscale_simulate(), betaregscale_simula_dados_z() now betaregscale_simulate_z().

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Mixed censoring support: complete likelihood (Eq. 2.24) now handles four censoring types simultaneously: exact (Œ¥=0\delta=0), left-censored (Œ¥=1\delta=1), right-censored (Œ¥=2\delta=2), interval-censored (Œ¥=3\delta=3). C++ backend rewrite: log-likelihood analytical gradient functions rewritten C++ (RcppArmadillo) numerically stable, high-performance evaluation. betareg-style S3 interface: coef() vcov() now accept model = c("full", "mean", "precision") argument. New S3 methods: nobs(), formula(), model.matrix(), confint(), plot(). confint() provides Wald confidence intervals based asymptotic normal approximation (z-test, t-test). plot() method six diagnostic panels (residuals vs indices, Cook‚Äôs distance, residuals vs linear predictor, residuals vs fitted, half-normal envelope, predicted vs observed) base R ggplot2 backends. censoring_summary() function visual tabular summaries censoring structure, base R ggplot2 backends. predict() expanded five types: "response", "link", "precision", "variance", "quantile". Supports newdata fixed variable dispersion models. residuals() supports five types: "response", "pearson", "rqr" (randomized quantile residuals), "weighted", "sweighted". summary() output now shows separate coefficient tables mean precision submodels Wald z-tests.

title: betaregscale 2.0.0
text: Fixed Pearson residual computation correctly dispatch reparameterization type (repar 1 vs repar 2). Fixed predict() newdata variable-dispersion models. Fixed p-values use pnorm() (standard normal) instead pt() (Student-t), consistent Wald inference theory (Eq. 2.34‚Äì2.35).

title: betaregscale 1.1.1
text: Initial public release bbmle-based fitting. Support fixed variable dispersion models. Basic S3 methods: coef, vcov, fitted, residuals, summary, print.
